Article 21 of the Constitution of India guarantees the protection of life and personal liberty. It ensures that no person shall be deprived of these rights except according to the procedure established by law.
Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code prescribes punishment for murder. It states that whoever commits murder shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life and shall also be liable to a fine.

Under Section 161 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, a police officer may examine orally any person supposed to be acquainted with the facts of a case during investigation. Statements so recorded can be used for limited purposes in court.

Section 66 of the Information Technology Act deals with computer-related offences such as hacking or unauthorized access. It prescribes imprisonment up to three years or a fine up to five lakh rupees, or both.
Section 24 of the Indian Evidence Act states that a confession caused by inducement, threat, or promise is inadmissible in court. This provision ensures that confessions are made voluntarily.
Section 73 of the Indian Contract Act provides that when a contract is broken, the injured party is entitled to compensation for loss or damage that naturally arises from the breach.
This section defines 'deficiency' in service, meaning any fault, imperfection, or inadequacy in the quality or manner of performance required by law or contract.
Section 185 of the Motor Vehicles Act makes driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs a punishable offence. It prescribes imprisonment up to six months and/or fine for the first offence.
This Article guarantees the fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression. It forms the cornerstone of democratic rights in India, though subject to reasonable restrictions.
Section 167 outlines the procedure when investigation cannot be completed within twenty-four hours. It empowers a magistrate to authorize police custody or judicial custody as per law.
